label: tɨh tẽ́h=n’àn tɨh ʔot-ʔë́ʔ=yɨʔ, “nɨ̀ põ'ra, nɨ̀ põ'ra!” tɨh no-ʔë́ʔ=yɨʔ=mah, yúp ʔɨd-ham-döhö-yɨ́ʔ-ay-áh.
trs: Crying for her children, saying, “My children, my children!” so saying, she transformed (into a bëbë bird).'{-}\footnotetext{This quoted speech combines two languages: the first word (‘my’) is in Hup, while the second word (‘children’) is in Tukano. As noted above, this multilingual quotation, together with the compound verb ‘say-do-transform' indexes the mother's transformation via the act of crying, i.e. speaking the “language" of the bëbë bird.}
